title: 105_hr1176
content: The United States aims to end animal suffering caused by steel jaw leghold traps by banning their import, export, and interstate shipment, along with fur from animals trapped in such traps. The Act defines "article of fur" as any furskin or article containing furskin, "interstate commerce" as defined in section 10 of title 18, and "import" as landing or introducing into the US jurisdiction. The term "steel jaw leghold trap" is defined as a spring-powered device with two steel jaws designed to capture an animal by snapping closed on its limb. The term "person" includes individuals, partnerships, corporations, and government entities subject to US jurisdiction. The term "Secretary" refers to the Secretary of the Interior. PROHIBITED ACTS AND PENALTIES. Prohibition on importing, exporting, or shipping fur derived from animals trapped in steel jaw leghold traps. Offenses include importing traps, selling or purchasing traps in violation, and penalties for violating regulations. Violation of regulations regarding importing, exporting, or shipping fur from animals trapped in steel jaw leghold traps results in penalties including fines and imprisonment for subsequent violations. SEC. 4. REWARDS. The Secretary will pay a reward to individuals providing information leading to a conviction under this Act, amounting to half of the fine paid. Government officials are not eligible for rewards. SEC. 5. ENFORCEMENT. The Secretary enforces the Act and regulations with the help of other agencies. Import violations are treated as customs law violations, while export violations are enforced using the Export Administration Act of 1979. The district courts of the United States may issue warrants for enforcement of the Act and any regulations. Authorities can detain, search, and seize packages suspected of containing articles in violation of the Act. Authorities can take action against violations of the Act, including making arrests without a warrant if there is probable cause. They can also execute warrants issued by judges for enforcement of the Act. (e) Forfeiture.--Any article of fur or steel jaw leghold trap taken, possessed, sold, purchased, offered for sale, imported, exported, transported, delivered, received, carried, or shipped in violation of this Act shall be subject to forfeiture to the United States, with provisions for seizure, forfeiture, condemnation, disposition of property or proceeds, remission or mitigation of forfeitures, and compromise of claims. The provisions of this subsection apply to seizures and forfeitures under this title. The Secretary or designated officers may perform duties related to property seizures. The Attorney General can seek injunctions for violations of the Act. The Secretary of Commerce must cooperate. Cooperation among relevant departments and agencies is required to ensure effective enforcement of the Act and its regulations. The Secretary will create necessary regulations for this Act to be implemented. The Act will become effective one year after its enactment.
